action.action-desc: Ms. Caraveo (for herself and Mr. Kean of New Jersey) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To direct the Comptroller General of the United States to conduct a study and submit a report on the efficacy of Federal drug surveillance systems, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Curbing Illicit Drug Threats Act.

section.header: GAO study and report on efficacy of Federal drug surveillance systems

subsection.text: The Comptroller General of the United States shall conduct a study on—

paragraph.text: the efficacy of Federal drug surveillance systems in providing up-to-date information on illicit drug use in the United States, including any limitations affecting such efficacy; and
how such systems are used to address illicit drug use in the United States.

subsection.text: Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General of the United States shall complete the study under subsection (a) and submit to Congress a report containing—

paragraph.text: the findings and conclusions of such study; and

any recommendations for legislative or administrative actions to improve the efficacy of the Federal drug surveillance systems examined in such study, including any recommendations pertaining to interagency communication or data collection procedures.

subsection.text: In this section, the term Federal drug surveillance systems includes—

paragraph.text: the Drug Overdose Surveillance and Epidemiology System of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (commonly known as DOSE);
the State Unintentional Drug Overdose Reporting System of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (commonly known as SUDORS);
the National Drug Early Warning System of the National Institute on Drug Abuse (commonly known as NDEWS); and
the Drug Abuse Warning Network of the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (commonly known as DAWN).
